thread.title: A Hallowe'en horror story facing our economy

author: Keith Rossiter
title: A Hallowe'en horror story facing our economy
text:
A Hallowe'en horror story facing our economy Vince Cable warns of tough times ahead Share Sir Vince Cable speaking at Exeter Science Park (Image: Guy Newman) Share Get Daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The medieval Great Hall at Dartington is a fitting setting for a Hallowe’en horror story, and Sir Vince Cable with his saturnine features has a similar ability to chill the blood. 
Certainly, the chill wind of reality seemed to blow through the Devon and Cornwall Business Council’s annual dinner in the Great Hall last week when the Liberal Democrat leader spoke. 
As Business Secretary in the 2010-15 government, Sir Vince is not casually scaremongering when he warns of tough times ahead. 
Our economic system had a major heart attack in 2008. We’re out of intensive care, but still hooked up to an IV line. The IV line carries cheap money, of course, and not a medical saline solution. Low interest rates and devaluation have pumped financial liquidity into the economy. Sir Vince Cable, with Tim Jones, chairman of Devon & Cornwall Business Council, left (Image: Andy Uglow, Pyramid Torbay Photography) 
“This is probably going to come to an end quite soon,” Sir Vince says. “Individuals and companies who are highly leveraged are going to find themselves in a much more uncomfortable world.” 
If life has seemed just about OK, it’s because we are in the midst of another consumer debt bubble of the kind before 2007. We’re racking up debt partly because of low wages, which in turn are linked to pathetic productivity that has flatlined for a decade.Few would be surprised to learn that productivity is higher in Germany and the United States. But France, and even Italy, easily outstrip us too. 
Cornwall’s productivity is 30% below the UK average, so is it any wonder that wages are low and poverty high? Read More Lib Dem leader Vince Cable tells South Devon business community to prepare for 'difficult problems ahead' 
Government has a role to play, but businesses need to invest. And just as boards were beginning to loosen the purse strings, along came Brexit, fangs bared and cloak flapping in the moonlight, to suck the blood out of the economy. 
Vampire movies end well, don’t they. And Sir Vince had a wake-up message for the Westcountry: pull together. 
We all know how it goes. Plymouth hates Exeter and vice versa, and Cornwall wishes the Tamar would crack apart and do a proper job of cutting them off. 
Meanwhile, Somerset pretends it is a kind of Greater Bristol with no connections to the country bumpkins to the west. 
We all hate politicians and civil servants in London, who ignore us. Government money is being doled out for regional development, but most of it is going to the “Midland Engine” and the “Northern Powerhouse”, to London and the South East. Read More 
Whitehall has “a bit of a blurred image” of the Westcountry, Sir Vince says. “It’s very much up to you to organise yourselves.” 
Birmingham, Coventry and Wolverhampton have done it, burying their differences and pulling together under an elected mayor. 
“I didn’t use to be in favour of these mayors,” he says. “But they do work” – even in rural areas such as Cambridgeshire. 
We can understand why politicians wave their strings of garlic at the terrifying, power-sapping idea. But if they really care about this region’s people, perhaps it is time to think again. Like us on Facebook
